abstract.p: Howard Goldberg reviews 1999 Spanish albarino wine from Martin Codax and 1998 Vina Godeval by Bodegas Godeval; photo (M)

block.p: Two whites from northwestern Spain, one extroverted and the other inward, fuel the at-home pleasures of summer: socializing and light fish and seafood meals.

Many wine lovers, even sophisticates, barely know the kaleidiscopic treats of crowd-pleasing alberino, a flirtatiously aromatic and delicious drink that at its best resembles weightless Mosel rieslings from Germany.
Two whites from northwestern Spain, one extroverted and the other inward, fuel the at-home pleasures of summer: socializing and light fish and seafood meals.

Many wine lovers, even sophisticates, barely know the kaleidiscopic treats of crowd-pleasing alberino, a flirtatiously aromatic and delicious drink that at its best resembles weightless Mosel rieslings from Germany.

In a good vintage, like '99, alberino is addictive. One of the best versions is Martin Codax. Like all alberinos, it comes from the Rias Baixas region of Galicia. Spaniards adore it with Atlantic fish, seafood and tapas. Crisp, zesty and fresh, the '99 is tropical in flavor, with hints of coconuts and spearmint, and animated by a spritz.

By contrast, '98 Vina Godeval, made by Bodegas Godeval from the rare godello grape in the Valdeorras Valley in Galicia, is a virtually unknown, smoky, mineral-like, somewhat austere wine that, more than alberino, wants surf fare. Its tantalizing crispness recalls Muscadet and young white Burgundies.

For the Martin Codax, Sutton Wine Shop, 403 East 57th Street, Manhattan, charges $13; Golden, 41-07 Bell Boulevard (41st Avenue), Bayside, Queens, $12. For the Vina Godeval, Heights Chateau, 131 Atlantic Avenue (Henry Street), Brooklyn, asks $14.
Both whites, imported and distributed by Tempranillo, in Mamaroneck, N.Y., come from the portfolio of Jorge Ordonez, a broker whose Spanish estates are standard-bearers on the East Coast.
